core_claim: The Antikythera mechanism, discovered in a 2,000-year-old shipwreck, is an ancient Greek analog computer capable of predicting eclipses and planetary positions.

supporting_details.date: Discovered in 1901; dated to around 150–100 BCE
supporting_details.location: Antikythera shipwreck, off the coast of Antikythera, Greece
supporting_details.participants: Greek sponge divers, archaeologist Valerios Stais
supporting_details.components: Over 30 bronze gears, dials, and inscriptions
supporting_details.function: Modeled celestial cycles, including the Metonic and Saros eclipse cycles

source_citation: Freeth, T., et al. (2006). 'Decoding the ancient Greek astronomical calculator known as the Antikythera Mechanism.' Nature 444, 587–591.
why_strange: Its complexity rivals 18th-century clockwork, yet it was made over 2,000 years ago

core_claim: The Baghdad Battery, a 2,000-year-old ceramic jar found in Iraq, may have functioned as a galvanic cell, predating modern batteries by centuries.

supporting_details.date: Discovered in 1936; estimated to date from 250 BCE to 250 CE
supporting_details.participants: Wilhelm König, German archaeologist and director of the National Museum of Iraq
supporting_details.components: Terracotta pot, copper cylinder, iron rod, possible acidic electrolyte
supporting_details.theory: Could produce about 1 volt of electricity

source_citation: König, Wilhelm (1940). 'Ein galvanisches Element aus der Partherzeit?' Forschungen und Fortschritte 16(7): 239–243.
why_strange: Suggests ancient civilizations may have experimented with electricity long before its documented discovery

core_claim: The Piri Reis map, drawn in 1513, depicts parts of South America and Antarctica with surprising accuracy, centuries before Antarctica was officially discovered.

supporting_details.location: Topkapi Palace, Istanbul, Turkey (where the map is held)
supporting_details.participants: Piri Reis, Ottoman admiral and cartographer
supporting_details.features: Detailed coastlines of South America and a landmass resembling ice-free Antarctica
supporting_details.materials: Compiled from older maps, possibly including ancient Greek or Phoenician sources

source_citation: McIntosh, Gregory C. (2000). 'The Piri Reis Map of 1513.' University of Georgia Press.
why_strange: It appears to show parts of Antarctica centuries before its official discovery in 1820
